AHOPE

AHOPE (Access, Harm Reduction, Overdose Prevention and Education) is a walk-in needle exchange program for active injection drug users located on Albany Street, in the same facility that is home to PAATHS.

The program provides integrated HIV, Hepatitis, and Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) testing, free, legal, and anonymous needle exchange, referrals to HIV, Hepatitis, and STI treatment, overdose prevention education and training, risk reduction supplies to reduce the spread of infection, and risk reduction counseling.

Services are available at the walk-in center, Monday through Friday, or via mobile van and outreach sites around Boston.

PAATHS

PAATHS (Providing Access to Addictions Treatment, Hope and Support) is a resource for individuals, families, community partners, and treatment providers who are directly affected by or work to prevent substance abuse disorders.

The staff at the Albany Street location assess an individual’s treatment needs, describes the types of treatment available, makes recommendations and referrals, facilitates access to different treatment programs, and connects clients to overdose prevention and risk reduction services -- all in collaboration with primary care providers and behavioral staff from emergency departments and primary care settings.

Individuals may access PAATHS walk-in services at the Albany Street location, on a first-come, first-served basis, and by hotline Monday through Friday.

content.text:
BHCHP

Boston Heath Care for the Homeless Program treats the thousands of individuals find themselves homeless in greater Boston every year. Among them are chronically ill adults, veterans, families with school-age children, and the elderly. They are the people who stay in emergency shelters or motel rooms, eat in soup kitchens, or visit drop-in centers. They are also the men and women who find themselves on the streets, trying to survive in makeshift shelters under bridges, down alleyways, and behind city buildings. Over 12,000 homeless men, women, and children are cared for by Boston Health Care for the Homeless Program each year. We are committed to ensuring that every one of these individuals has access to comprehensive health care, from preventative dental care to cancer treatment. Our clinicians, case managers, and behavioral health professionals work in more than 60 locations to deliver the highest quality health care to some of our community’s most vulnerable—and most resilient—citizens.
